title: Vice President Photographed In Front Of A Truly Star-Studded American Flag
text:
Vice President Photographed In Front Of A Truly Star-Studded American Flag "... is it an intentional snub ..." by Fred Maxwell February 20, 2017 at 4:23pm Share on Facebook 507 Tweet Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
When Vice President Mike Pence spoke in Brussels Monday, he was photographed standing in front of an American flag. 
Some observers, however, quickly noticed something unusual about the version of Old Glory displayed at the European Union event. 
It had 51 stars rather that 50. Advertisement - story continues below Historian Launches His Countdown To The Pence Presidency 
The official flag of the United States contains nine alternating rows of six and five stars. 
Photographs show the flag in Brussels with three rows of nine stars alternating with three rows of eight stars. 
Media inquiries into the reason for the extra star were not readily answered by the EU Council. Advertisement – story continues below 
Pence was meeting with European Council President Donald Tusk when the inaccurate picture of the flag made its appearance. The reports @MunSecConf of the death of the West have been greatly exaggerated. #MSC2017 pic.twitter.com/TajxoQkpxe 
— Donald Tusk (@eucopresident) February 20, 2017 
According to the Brussels Times , the vice president was visiting Brussels in “the second stage of a European tour designed to reassure concerned allies about the White House’s new occupant Donald Trump, who wants Europe to contribute more to the collective defence.” Advertisement - story continues below 
During the meeting, Pence confirmed that the United States is “totally committed” to NATO. @BBCNews is it an intentional snub having 51 stars on the American flag behind Pence? 
— Richard Keir (@keirrichard) February 20, 2017 
The current American flag was designed in 1958 by Robert Heft, a high school student, as an assignment in his history class in anticipation of the addition of Alaska and Hawaii. 
Although Heft only received a B-minus for his design, he sent a prototype of his design to the White House, where President Dwight Eisenhower chose it for the new flag. 
His history project grade was increased to an A. 
The Brussels incident was not the first time a 51-star flag has made an appearance.
